Fixed issue whereby an inherited autoproperty with private setter was not correctly mapped with access=backfield.

This was due to a bug in the logic for determining whether a member is an autoproperty. Fixed multiple instance of same ComponentMap bug

A setup satisfying the following:

  * An entity with two components of the same type, each with it's own
    prefix
  * A ComponentMap for the above component type, with explicit columns
    being used

Would cause columns to be mapped with both prefixes. This was due to
effectively the same instance of component being assigned to each
property. Without the explicit columns, default ones are used which
aren't shared between the instances; however, with the prefixes both
components shared a column instance. When the prefix visitor was applied
to the shared column, it received both prefxies.

I've implemented deep cloning using binary serialization to remedy this.
I was against using this method previously because I think it's hacky,
but it seems like the only acceptable solution besides hand-rolling a
deep copy mechanism (which I'm not doing).

The change made in 894d218 which added an order to the type sources had

that the automapper relied on. This fix introduces an order on the

object from the current type. Types with the least depth are mapped
first, meaning parents are mapped before their children.

Implement property-level equality comparison specification in addition to the entity-level one and add tests.

If there is no property-level equality comparer the code will fall-back to the entity-level comparer and if neither are set simply to Object.Equals.

An example:

    new PersistenceSpecification<Food> (base.Session, new EntityLevelEqualityComparer ())
        .CheckProperty (food => food.Image, new Bitmap (20, 20), new BitmapEqualityComparer ())
        .CheckProperty (food => food.Brand, "banana")
        .VerifyTheMappings ();

Here for the property Image the BitmapEqualityComparer will be used and for the property Brand the EntityLevelEqualityComparer.

Fix bug 54 so that it is now possible to use chained property references when testing components or one-to-one references. E.g.:

    new PersistenceSpecification<User> (base.Session)
        .CheckProperty (user => user.Preferences.DailyCaloriesTarget, 1500)

Without this commit Fluent NHibernate will throw trying to set the value on "user.DailyCaloriesTarget" instead of user.Preferences.DailyCaloriesTarget.

Automated the generation of many-to-many table names, uni and bi directional.

Bi directional many-to-many's now attempt to find the other side of the relationship and set both sides to be the same thing; if one side is explicitly set in the mapping then the other side will inherit it, if none are set the one will be generated. It will locate the other side by finding any many-to-many's on the child entity that are a collection of the parent, and optionally look at the property names if there is more than one many-to-many of the same type.

The only situation it can't cope with is if you have more than one many-to-many of the same type on the same two entities, with one of them not having a logically discernable name.

Implemented support for defining subclasses outside of their parent.

It is now possible to define a subclass in the same way that you do a normal class, you just derive from SubclassMap<YourEntity> in the same manner as you would ClassMap<YourEntity>.

One important thing to know is that there isn't a distinction between subclasses and joined-subclasses, you map them both the same way. It will be determined by inspecting the parent mapping as to whether the subclass you've defined is joined or not; this is done by looking for a discriminator definition on the parent. To use subclasses instead of joined-subclasses just call DiscriminateSubclassesOnColumn in your parent's ClassMap.

git-svn-id: https://fluent-nhibernate.googlecode.com/svn/trunk@144 48f0ce17-cc52-0410-af8c-857c09b6549b

This branch modifies the existing solution to add 3 new projects:
- FluentNHibernate2
- FluentNHibernate2.BackwardCompatibility
- FluentNHibernate2.Testing

FluentNHibernate2 is the new core assembly. It contains the current progress on developing a semantic model for configuring nhibernate mappings. I also implemented a very small subset of the existing fluent api - this resides in FluentNHibernate2.BackwardCompatibility. The intention is to demonstrate that this rewrite supports the possibility of multiple fluent apis that each map to the same underlying model. To see the backward compatible fluent api in action, take a look at BackwardCompatibility/MusicMappingTester.cs. 

The intention of this branch is to act as an example of how the fluent aspects of this project can be seperated from the aspect of building nhibernate hbm xml. This branch has a LONG way to go before it could be considered as a possible replacement for the trunk. There are some significant issues to be worked out:

- Dealing with changes to the generated Hbm* classes is going to be hell. There are a few different ways this issue can be approached, but I have no idea if any of them have a chance of being successful. Need to look at the possibility of building the hbm graph in one hit, rather than incrementally, probably via the visitor pattern. It is also worth looking at the HbmGenerator project within NHibernate, see if changes can be made there, or, possibly to the partial classes with NHibernate.dll that augment the Hbm* classes.

- The trunk API supports enough of nhibernate mapping to be useful to some users. The api in this branch needs to be filled out significantly before the same can be said of it.

- No support for conventions or automapping. These are the most attractive features to many of the higher profile community members. This branch needs a proper treatment of these concepts before it can be taken seriously.

Final Note:
The projects include the "2" in the name simply because I found it most useful to maintain a solution that contains both the old code and the new code. The "2" will be removed should this branch progress far enough that is no longer necessary to include the original projects in the solution. So far I have only brought over functionality from the original projects when it was necessary, for example FluentNHibernate2/Cfg and FluentNHibernate2/Reflection. In both of these cases I tried to move the entire block of functionality over as is.
